journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part C: Journal of Mechanical Engineering Science

title-group.article-title: A two-dimensional free vibration analysis of functionally graded sandwich beams under thermal environment

article-meta.aff: 1Faculty of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Shiraz University of Technology, Iran
2Department of Mechanical Engineering, Ferdowsi University of Mashhad, Iran
3Department of Mechanical Engineering, School of Engineering, Persian Gulf University, Iran

author-notes.corresp: AR Setoodeh, Faculty of Mechanical and Aerospace Engineering, Shiraz University of Technology, Shiraz, Iran. Email: setoodeh@sutech.ac.ir; asetood@yahoo.com

abstract.p: In this article, free vibration analysis of elastically supported sandwich beams with functionally graded face sheets subjected to thermal environment is presented. In order to accurately include the transverse shear deformation and the inertia effects, two-dimensional elasticity theory is used to formulate the problem. The layerwise theory in conjunction with the differential quadrature method is employed to discretize the governing equations in the thickness and axial directions, respectively. The material properties of functionally graded face sheets are assumed to be temperature-dependent and graded in the thickness direction according to a power-law distribution. For the purpose of comparison, the problem under consideration is also solved using two-dimensional finite element method and the first-order shear deformation theory. The accuracy, convergence, and versatility of the method are demonstrated by comparing the results with those of the two aforementioned approaches and also with the existing solutions in literature. Eventually, some new numerical results are presented which depict the effects of different material and geometrical parameters on natural frequencies and mode shapes of the beam.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The recent advances in design and manufacturing technologies have greatly enhanced the use of sandwich structures in a variety of engineering applications including marine, aerospace, and transportation.1 Although sandwich structures offer advantages over other types of structures, it is important to develop new types of multi-functional hybrid materials which play an important role on the design of future structures. The mechanical behavior of sandwich structures is dependent on both the mechanical properties of the core and the sandwich skins. Functionally grade sandwich composites with functionally graded (FG) face sheets and homogeneous core layer are known as a new generation of advanced structures. In fact, the structural performance of the composite is improved by incorporating novel materials for the face sheets.2–4 Functionally graded materials (FGMs) are usually constructed from composition of metal and ceramic. These composites possess properties that vary gradually and continuously with respect to the spatial coordinates in order to achieve a required function. They are able to withstand higher temperature gradients while maintaining their structural integrity.5

The free vibration analyses of conventional sandwich and also FGM beams have been reported in the open literature. Some recently published researches in this regards are reviewed here. Zhen and Wanji6 developed the Navier’s solution for free vibration and stability analysis of simply supported laminated composite and sandwich beams using several displacement-based theories. Alashti and Kashiri7 investigated the effect of temperature variation on free vibration of a simply supported curved sandwich beam with a flexible core. Ying et al.8 introduced an analytical solution for bending and free vibration of FGM beams. Sina et al.9 proposed a new beam theory based on the first-order shear deformation theory (FSDT) for analytical free vibration analysis of FGM beams. Malekzadeh et al.10 studied the out-of-plane free vibration of FG circular curved beams in thermal environment. Huang and Li11 presented a new approach for free vibration of axially FG beams with non-uniform cross-section. Alshorbagy et al.12 presented the free vibration analysis of FG beams based on Euler–Bernoulli beam theory using numerical finite element (FE) method. Mahi et al.13 proposed an analytical method for temperature-dependent free vibration analysis of FG beams with general boundary conditions. Shahba et al.14 considered free vibration and stability analysis of axially FG tapered Timoshenko beams employing FE method. Wattanasakulpong et al.15 employed a third-order shear deformation theory to analyze free vibration of layered FG beams.

Despite of wide amount of literature available on modeling and analysis of FGM beams, studies on free vibration analyses of functionally graded sandwich (FGS) beams with FG face sheets and homogeneous core layer are rare in the literature, and it will be the main focus of this article. Moreover, the FGM properties have been mostly considered to be constant and only few researches have been examined temperature-dependent material properties on the thermo-mechanical responses of FGMs. Xiang and Yang16 studied free and forced vibration of a FGS Timoshenko beam under heat conduction using differential quadrature method (DQM). The material properties of FGMs were assumed to be independent of temperature. Pradhan and Murmu17 studied thermo-mechanical vibration of both FGM and FGS beams resting on variable Winkler and two-parameter elastic foundation using the Euler–Bernoulli theory.

The models that have been usually employed to study the mechanical behavior of FGM beams are based on equivalent single-layer theories (ESLTs). In these models, the layered structure is replaced with a statically equivalent single layer whose stiffness is a weighted average of the layer stiffness through the thickness. Thus, they are only capable of introducing global displacement and strain approximations in the thickness direction. This motivated us to extend displacement-based layerwise theory for the FGS beams for the first time. Displacement-based layerwise theories assume a separate displacement field within each subdivision. Therefore, layerwise theory improves the displacement field approximation compared to ESLTs. Furthermore, this theory has the advantage of being computationally less expensive than three-dimensional elasticity theory.18 There are only a few solutions which have used the layerwise theory to model the free vibration behavior of beams.19,20

Besides using a reliable theory, the accuracy, and efficiency of method of solution are other important parameters in studying the laminated FG beams. Differential quadrature (DQ) is a numerical technique that has been used since 1988 for the analysis of structural elements. Bert and Malik21 presented a review of the early developments in DQM. Malekzadeh and his co-workers22,23 exhibited that using DQM for solving the governing equations of different mechanical problems leads to highly accurate results with less computations.

In this study, the free vibration analysis of FGS beams under thermal environment and resting on elastic foundation is investigated using DQM. The two-dimensional (2D) layerwise theory is used to improve the displacement field with minimum computational cost. In order to obtain a comparative solution, the problem is also modeled using FSDT as well as 2D FE method. To the best of our knowledge, a study to investigate the free vibration analysis of FGS beams under thermal environment based on the first-order shear deformation or the layerwise theories has not been performed before. In order to present a realistic model, the beam is considered to be initially under thermal environment. Thus, the thermally induced initial stresses are first determined which rarely has been considered in previous studies of composite structures. Afterwards, the frequencies of the beam are calculated using predetermined thermally induced stresses. The accuracy, versatility, and efficiency of the method are demonstrated by comparing the results with the solutions of ABAQUS and FSDT presented by authors. Some comparisons with the solution of homogenous and composite beams available in the literature are also performed.

sec.title: Material properties
sec.p:
Consider a symmetric FGS beam having length L and the total thickness h with respect to a Cartesian coordinate system x–z, as shown in Figure 1. The FGS beam is composed of two outer FGM layers and a homogeneous core. The face sheets are made of a FGM with the material properties varying smoothly in the z-direction, having a thickness of hf and are perfectly bonded with the core. The core is constituted by an isotropic homogeneous material like metal and has a thickness of hs. The beam is resting on a two-parameter elastic foundation with the foundation moduli of Kw and Kp , respectively. A typical effective material property (P) for face layers such as modulus of elasticity E, Poisson’s ratio ν , and coefficient of thermal conductivity K through the thickness of the FGS beam is expressed as (1)P(T,z)=[Pc(T,z)-Pm(T,z)]Vc(z)+Pm(T,z) where Pm and Pc denote the corresponding temperature-dependent properties of metal and ceramic, respectively, Vc also the volume fraction of the ceramic for upper and lower layers and varies according to the following power-law (2) Vc(z)=[χzhf-hs2hf]n where n stands for the power-law index and χ takes values of 1 or −1 for the upper and lower layers, respectively. Due to significant changes in mechanical properties of the ingredient materials in extremely high temperature environments, the properties of materials are considered to be a function of the environment temperature as (3)P=P0(P-1T-1+1+P1T+P2T2+P3T3) where the coefficients Pi(i = −1, 0, 1, 2, 3) are unique to the constituent materials. For the FGS beam, the temperature variation is considered to be in the thickness direction. It is assumed that the temperature at the upper and the lower surfaces to be held at TU and TL , respectively. Thus, the temperature distribution is obtained by solving the Fourier equation of heat conduction (4)-ddz(K(T,z)dT(z)dz)=0
Figure 1.
Geometry of the FGS beam. FGS, functionally graded sandwich.

The continuity requirements at the interfaces of face sheet-core yield to the following relations (5)T(1)|z=-hs/2=T(2)|z=-hs/2, T(2)|z=hs/2=T(3)|z=hs/2K(1)dTdz|z=-hs/2=K(2)dTdz|z=-hs/2,K(2)dTdz|z=hs/2=K(3)dTdz|z=hs/2 where (K(1),K(2),K(3)) and (T(1),T(2),T(3)) are the thermal conductivity coefficient and the temperature of the lower FGM layer, the metallic core and the upper FGM layer, respectively. The solution of equation (4) is obtained in the following form16 (6)T(m)=a1 (m)+a2 (m)∫ zm-1 z1K(m) dz, (m=1,2,3) where (7)a1 (1)=TL, a2 (1)=a2 (2)=a2 (3)=TU-TLt(1)+t(2)+t(3),a1 (2)=TL+t(1)t(1)+t(2)+t(3)(TU-TL)a1 (3)=TL+t(1)+t(2)t(1)+t(2)+t(3)(TU-TL),(m)=∫ zm-1 zm1K(m) dz, (m=1,2,3)
zm-1 and zm denote the z-coordinates of the lower and upper surfaces of the mth layer.

sec.title: Thermoelastic equilibrium analysis
sec.p: To determine the thermally induced initial stresses, the through-the-thickness discretized form of the 2D thermoelastic equilibrium equations are first derived using layerwise theory. The beam is considered to be initially stress-free at the temperature T0. If the beam operates in a thermal environment, non-uniform temperature rise, non-uniformity of the material properties, or mechanical constraints at its edges cause some stresses in it. These stresses affect the vibration characteristic of the beams. Hereafter, a subscript ‘0’ is used to represent the variables in the equilibrium state of the beam in thermal environment.

Based on the layerwise theory, the displacement field is assumed to be of the following form (8)u0(x,z)=Ui 0(x) ϕi(z), w0(x,z)=Wi 0(x) ϕi(z), (i=1,…,Nz) where u0 and w0 are the displacement components in the x- and z-direction, respectively, Ui 0 and Wi 0 the displacement components at the ith plane ( z=zi ) in the x- and z-direction, respectively, ϕi a continuous function in terms of the thickness coordinate z that usually introduced as global interpolation function, also Nz the number of nodes in the z-direction of the beam, which depends on the number of considered mathematical layers Ne through the thickness.18

The global linear shape function is defined as below (9)ϕi(z)={ 0 z≤zi-1(z-zi-1)/hi-1 zi-1≤z≤zi(zi+1-z)/hi zi≤z≤zi+1 0 z≥zi+1 , i=1, 2,…,Nz where hi is the thickness of the ith layer and zi the z-coordinate of ith surface. Using the layerwise theory and the 2D elasticity theory, the linear strain–displacement relations become (10)ɛ0xx=dUi 0dxφi, ɛ0zz=Wi 0dφidz,2ɛ0xz=Ui 0dφidz+dWi 0dxφi where ɛ0ij(i,j=x,z) are the strain tensor components.
Using equation (10) in conjunction with the principle of virtual work, the thermoelastic equilibrium equations together with the related boundary conditions are obtained as

Equilibrium equations (11)δUi: dN0x idx-Q0x i=0
(12)δWi: dR0x idx-M0z i-Kw W1 0 δi1+Kpd2W1 0dx2 δi1=0 Boundary conditions (13)Either Ui 0=0 or N0x i=0
(14)Either Wi 0=0 or R0x i+KPd W1 0dxδi1=0 where δi1 is the Kronecker delta and the following definitions of the stress resultants are introduced (15)(N0x i,R0x i)=∫-h2 h2(σ0xx,σ0xz) φi dz, (Q0x i,M0z i)=∫-h2 h2(σ0xz,σ0zz) dφidz dz where σ0ij(i,j=x,z) are the stress tensor components. Assuming the plane stress condition in each layer, the thermoelastic constitutive relations at an arbitrary point of a beam can then be written as (16){σ0xxσ0zzσ0xz}=[C11C130C13C33000C55]{ɛ0xx-α ΔTɛ0zz-α ΔT2ɛ0xz} where α is the coefficient of thermal expansion and ΔT=T-T0 the temperature rise at an arbitrary material point of the beam. Also, the elastic coefficients are defined as (17)C11=C33=E(1-ν2), C13=ν C11, C55=E2(1+ν)

Consequently, using equation (15) and the stress–strain relations, one can express the stress resultants in terms of the displacement components as follows (18)eqalignno(N0x i,M0z i)=(A11 ij,B13 ji)dUj 0dx +(B13 ij,D33 ij) Wj 0-(Nx i(T),Mz i(T))(R0x i,Q0x i)=(B55 ij,D55 ij)Uj 0+(A55 ij,B55 ji)dWj 0dx

In the above equations, the beam stiffnesses and the thermal resultant stresses are defined as below (19)Amnij=∫−h2h2Cmn ϕi ϕjdz, Bmnij=∫−h2h2Cmn ϕidϕjdzdz,Dmnij=∫−h2h2Cmndϕidz dϕjdzdz
(20)Nx i(T)=∫-h2 h2(C11+C13) α ΔT φidz,Mz i(T)=∫-h2 h2(C13+C33) α ΔT dφidz dz

Inserting equation (18) into equations (11) and (12), leads to the following thermoelastic equilibrium equations together with the related boundary conditions expressed in terms of the displacement components.

Equilibrium equations (21)A11 ijd2Uj 0dx2-D55 ij Uj 0+(B13 ij-B55 ji) dWj 0dx-dNx i(T)dx=0
(22)(B55 ij-B13 ji) dUj 0dx+A55 ijd2Wj 0dx2-D33 ij Wj 0 -Kw W1 0 δi1+Kpd2W1 0dx2 δi1+Mz i(T)=0 Boundary conditions (23)Either Ui 0=0 or A11 ijdUj 0dx+B13 ij Wj 0-Nx i(T)=0
(24)Either Wi 0=0 or B55 ij Uj 0+A55 ijdWj 0dx+Kp dW1 0dx δi1=0

sec.title: Vibration analysis
sec.p: In order to investigate the free vibration characteristic of the FGS beam under thermal environment, the displacement components of an arbitrary material point (x, z) are perturbed around its equilibrium position. Hence, the total displacement components measured from the beam undeformed configuration become u(x,z,t)+u0(x,z) and w(x,z,t)+w0(x,z) along the x- and z-direction, respectively. According to layerwise theory, the displacement field of the FGS beam can be expressed as (25)u(x,z,t)=Ui(x,t) ϕi(z), w(x,z,t)=Wi(x,t) ϕi(z)

For vibration analysis, the definition of variables is identical to the corresponding definition presented in the thermoelastic analysis. In this study, we aim to figure out the effects of the initial stresses due to thermal environment in the equations of motion. Therefore, it is needed to take into consideration the non-linear strain–displacement relations, as follows (26)ɛxx=∂u∂x+12(∂w∂x)2, ɛzz=∂w∂z, 2ɛxz=∂u∂z+∂w∂x
Substituting equation (25) into the above strain–displacement relations yields (27)ɛxx=∂Ui∂xϕi+12(∂Wi∂x)(∂Wj∂x)ϕiϕj,ɛzz=Widφidz, 2ɛxz=Uidφidz+∂Wi∂xφi

To derive the governing differential equations together with the related boundary conditions, Hamilton’s principle is employed (28)∫0 t(δ U+δ Uef-δ KT) dt=0 where δ is the variational symbol, KT the total kinetic energy, U the strain energy, and Uef the foundations potential energy. Including initial thermal stresses, the strain energy can be written in the following form (29)δ U=∫0 L∫A [ (σxx+σ0xx )δ ( ɛxx+ɛ0xx ) + (σzz+σ0zz )δ ( ɛzz+ɛ0zz ) +2 (σxz+σ0xz )δ ( ɛxz+ɛ0xz ) ] dA dx

In equation (29), A is the beam area. It is worth noting that the strain field is found at the state of the thermoelastic equilibrium (i.e. δɛ0xx=δɛ0zz=δɛ0xz=0 ). Hence, equation (29) is reduced to (30)δ U=∫0 L∫A[(σxx+σ0xx) δɛxx+(σzz+σ0zz) δɛzz +2(σxz+σ0xz) δɛxz] dA dx

Also, the potential energy of the foundation and the kinetic energy are expressed as (31)δ Uef=∫0 L[Kw (W1+W1 0) δ W1 +Kp (∂W1∂x+dW1 0dx) ∂δ W1∂x]dx
(32)δ KT=∫0 L∫Aρ [∂u∂t ∂δ u∂t+∂w∂t ∂δ w∂t] dA dx=∫0 LIij[∂Ui∂t ∂δ Uj∂t+∂Wi∂t ∂δ Wj∂t] dx

Eventually, the governing equations of motion together with the related boundary conditions are derived using equations (28) through (32) and carrying out a typical variation process.20 The results are

Governing equations (33)δUi: ∂Nx i∂x-Qx i+∂N0x i∂x-Q0x i=Iij U··j
(34)δWi: ∂Rx i∂x-Mz i+dR0x idx-M0z i+∂∂x(N~0x ij∂Wj∂x)-Kw (W1+W1 0) δi1+Kp(∂2W1∂x2+d2W1 0dx2) δi1=IijW··j Boundary conditions (35)Either Ui=0 or Nx i+N0x i=0
(36)Either Wi=0 or Rx i+R0x i+N~0x ij∂Wj∂x +Kp∂W1∂xδi1+KpdW1 0dxδi1=0 where a dot over a variable denotes the partial differentiation with respect to time (t). It is to be noted that above equations should satisfy the thermoelastic equilibrium equations (11) and (12); therefore, the governing equations of motion and the boundary conditions become:

Governing equations (37)δUi: ∂Nx i∂x-Qx i=Iij U··j
(38)δWi: ∂Rx i∂x-Mz i+∂∂x(N~0x ij∂Wj∂x)-Kw W1 δi1+Kp∂2W1∂x2 δi1=IijW··j

Boundary conditions (39)Either Ui=0 or Nx i=0
(40)Either Wi=0 or Rx i+N~0x ij∂Wj∂x+Kp∂W1∂xδi1=0 where we have (41)(Nx i,Rx i)=∫-h2 h2(σxx,σxz)φidz,(Qx i,Mz i)=∫-h2 h2(σxz,σzz)dφidzdz,Iij=∫-h2 h2ρφiφjdz, N~0x ij=∫-h2 h2σ0xx φi φj dz

In the above equations ρ denotes the mass density. Considering the small amplitude vibration assumption, the stress resultants and thermally induced stress can be expressed in terms of displacement components as below (42)(Nx i,Mz i)=(A11 ij,B13 ji)∂Uj∂x+(B13 ij,D33 ij) Wj, (Rx i,Qx i)=(B55 ij,D55 ij)Uj+(A55 ij,B55 ji)∂Wj∂xN~0x ij=A11 ijkdUK 0dx+B13 ijkWK 0-N~x ij (T) where (43)Amn ijk=∫-h2 h2Cmn φi φj φk dz, Bmn ijk=∫-h2 h2Cmn φi φjdφkdz dz,N~x ij (T)=∫-h2 h2(C11+C13) α ΔT φiφj dz

Governing equations (44)A11 ij∂2Uj∂x2-D55 ij Uj+(B13 ij-B55 ji) ∂Wj∂x=IijU··j
(45)(B55 ij-B13 ji) ∂Uj∂x+A55 ij∂2Wj∂x2-D33 ij Wj+∂∂x(N~0x ij∂Wj∂x) -Kw W1 δi1+Kp∂2W1∂x2 δi1=IijW··j Boundary conditions (46)Either Ui=0 or A11 ij∂Uj∂x+B13 ij Wj=0
(47)Either Wi=0 or B55 ij Uj+A55 ij∂Wj∂x+N~0x ij∂Wj∂x +Kp ∂W1∂x δi1=0

sec.title: DQ solution method
sec.p: The essence of the DQM is that the partial derivative of a field variable at the ith discrete point in the computational domain is approximated by a weighted linear summation of the field variable at all discrete nodes located along the line that passes through that point in the domain.

In order to illustrate the DQ approximation, consider a function f(ξ) defined on a domain 0≤ξ≤L . Based on the DQM, the rth derivative of function f(ξ) at point ξi is approximated as (48)∂rf(ξ)∂ξr|ξ=ξi=∑j=1 NxCij (r)f(ξj), r=1 , 2,. . . , Nx-1 where Nx is the total number of grid points in the x-direction, ξj the location of grid points, and Cij (r) the weighted coefficients associated with the rth derivative. For the sake of brevity, the DQ discretization rules are not brought here. For further details, the reader is referred to the works of Malekzadeh et al.20

Employing this method, the thermoelastic equilibrium equations and the related boundary conditions (11) to (14) are transformed into a set of linear algebraic equations, which can be easily solved using a standard system of algebraic equation solver. Consequently, the initial thermal resultant stress at each DQ grid points can be determined from equation (42) as (49)(N~0x ij)R=A11 ijk ∑m=1 NxCRm (1) UmK 0 +B13 ijk WRK 0-(N~x ij (T))R, R=2,…,Nx-1
Eventually, the DQM discretized form of the governing differential equations and the associated boundary conditions are developed.
Governing equations (R=2,…,Nx-1, i, j=1,…,Nz) Equation (44) (50)A11 ij∑m=1 NxCRm (2)Umj-D55 ij URj +(B13 ij-B55 ji)∑m=1 NxCRm (1)Wmj=IijU··Rj

Equation (45) (51)(B55 ij-B13 ji)∑m=1 NxCRm (1) Umj+A55 ij∑m=1 NxCRm (2)Wmj -D33 ij WRj+(N~0x ij)R∑m=1 NxCRm (2) Wmj +(dN~0x ijdx)R ∑m=1 NxCRm (1) Wmj-Kw WR1 δi1 +Kp δi1∑m=1 NxCRm (2) Wm1=Iij W··Rj Boundary conditions ( i, j=1,…,Nz )

Clamped (52)URi=WRi=0, R=1, Nx Simply support (53)WRi=0, A11 ij ∑m=1 NxCRm (1) Umj+B13 ijWRj=0 if i≠NmURi=0 if i=Nm., R=1 or Nx where Nm is the number of the mid-surface layer of the beam. To establish the eigenvalue system of equations, the degrees of freedom are separated into the domain and the boundary degrees of freedom. In vector forms, they are denoted as δd and δb , respectively. Based on this definition, equations (50) to (53) are rewritten as (54)Sddδd+Sdbδb+Mδ··d=0
(55)Sbbδb+Sbdδd=0 where S and M are the coefficient matrices and also subscripts b and d the domain and the boundary, respectively. The boundary degrees of freedom are eliminated from equation (54) using equation (55), and then by substituting δd(t) = Δd eiωt, the following eigenvalue problem is achieved. Here, ω is the natural frequency and Δd the vibration mode shape vector (56)( (Sdd-Sdb Sbb -1 Sbd)-ω2M) Δd=0
Solving the above equation, natural frequencies as well as mode shapes of the FGS beam under an initial thermal stress are predicted.

sec.title: Results
sec.p:
In this section, numerical results are presented for the free vibration analysis of FGS beams. In the following examples, the beam is assumed to be composed of silicon nitride (Si3N4) and stainless steel (SUS304)22,24 with a constant thermal conductivity of equal to 9.19 and 12.04 W/mK, respectively, unless otherwise stated. Also, the other material properties are temperature-dependent and given in Table 1. For simplicity and comparison with other numerical results, several non-dimensional parameters are introduced as Ω=ω LIm/Am,Im=ρ~h,Am=E~h1-ν~2,K¯w=KwL4E~I0,K¯p=KpL2π2E~I0,I0=Bh312
Table 1.
Temperature-dependent coefficients for ceramic and metal.
Material Properties P−1 P0 P1 × 104 P2 × 107 P3 × 1011
Si3N4 E (Pa) 0 348.43 × 109 −3.070 2.160 −8.946
α (1/K)
0 5.8723 × 10−6 9.095 0 0
ν
0 0.24 0 0 0
ρ (kg/m3)
0 2370 0 0 0
SUS304 E (Pa) 0 201.04 × 109 3.079 −6.534 0
α (1/K)
0 12.33 × 10−6 8.086 0 0
ν 0 0.3262 −2.002 3.797 0
ρ (kg/m3)
0 8166 0 0 0

The beam is assumed to have a unit width B throughout the analysis. Also, E~ , ρ~ , and ν~ are the Young’s modulus, the density, and the Poisson’s ratio of metal at the reference temperature, respectively. Moreover, the following quantities are adopted in numerical examples, unless otherwise stated L/h=10, hf/h=0.1, n=2, K¯w=0, K¯p=0

In this study, two states of the temperature gradient are considered. In the first case, the temperature of the bottom surface and the top surface is increased by ΔT with respect to the reference temperature, i.e. ΔTU=ΔTL=ΔT , while in the second case, the temperature of the bottom surface is held fixed as the reference temperature and the temperature of the top surface is increased by ΔT , i.e. ΔTU=ΔT, ΔTL=0 .

As a first step, the convergence study is carried out so that the number of nodes in the x- and z-direction required for an accurate solution of the problem can be determined. Then, in order to ensure the validity and accuracy of the present method, some results are obtained for isotropic and composite beams and compared with other results reported in the literature. Eventually, the effects of volume fraction index and various geometric parameters on the natural frequencies of FGS beams are investigated. In addition, to demonstrate a comprehensive comparison, FGS beams are modeled using the FSDT as well as the FE-based software ABAQUS. Quadrilateral elements (CPS4R) are used for the vibration analysis and DC2D4 type elements for the thermoelastic modeling.

sec.title: Convergence study
sec.p:
The dimensionless natural frequencies for beams with different geometrical parameters are presented in Table 2. The results are predicted by altering the number of grid points in the axial direction and the number of numerical layers across the thickness. Both moderately thick and thick beams are considered. For mesh designation, a 3 × 2 × 3 mesh means three divisions in the lower FGM layer, two divisions in the metallic core, and three divisions in the upper FGM layer across the thickness. The results are demonstrated for clamped FGS beams resting on elastic foundation K¯w=100 and subjected to a non-uniform temperature change of ΔT=300 . The layerwise solutions are also compared successfully with those obtained using ABAQUS software. The 2D FE computation is performed with 50 elements along the length and 30 discrete layers through the thickness of the beam. For all cases, fast rates of convergence of the method are quite evident. It is seen that the convergence rate depends on the both aspect and thickness ratios. Based on this observation, hereafter, 15 grid points are used to discretize the beam along the x-direction, unless otherwise stated. It is to be noted that the present results show excellent agreement with those obtained by the FE solution. Due to coupling of the layerwise theory with the DQM (named LW-DQ), the authors believe that the developed method yields more accurate results with respect to ABAQUS solution with less effort,20 although the maximum relative error is less than 1%. The DQ method is an efficient and accurate numerical approach in comparison with the weighted residual methods like FE method. The weak form of governing equations is solved in FE method, while DQ method discretizes the strong form of the governing equations. Furthermore, vice versa of FE, DQ exactly satisfies all types of boundary conditions. In the FE modeling, the properties of each layer are considered to be equal to those of its mid surface. Thus, a step-wise approximation of the material gradation represents a further approximation in the FE model. This type of solution requires a higher computational cost compared to present approach. A comparative study of the efficiency of the DQ-based solutions (LW-DQ and FSDT) and FE method is presented in Table 2 to demonstrate the effectiveness of the DQ method. The values inside the parentheses are the computational time, in seconds for the case of moderately thick beam. It is seen that FE software ABAQUS uses more CPU time than the present approach for the same problem. In other words, the DQ method is enable to reduce the computational time. Table 2.

sec.title: Validation
sec.p:
In order to validate the present method, an isotropic homogeneous simply supported beam resting on elastic foundations is considered here. In Table 3, the dimensionless natural frequencies for beams resting on elastic foundation are compared with the solutions of classic beam theory (CBT), FSDT and those achieved in reference25 using an exact power series expansion. The first three solutions are developed employing DQM. Excellent agreement is observed between the present results and the exact solution. Table 3.
Comparison of dimensionless natural frequencies of an isotropic simply supported beam ( L/h=5, υ=0.3 , Ω=ωL2ρ/Eh2 , Nx=15, Ne=20 ).
K¯w
K¯p
CBT FSDT Exact25 LW-DQ

CBT, classic beam theory; FSDT, first-order shear deformation theory.

Tables 4 presents the dimensionless natural frequencies of simply supported composite beams predicted by different theories. The numerical results are determined for Nx=13 and Ne=20 , while the material layers have the same thickness. The results in reference6 are determined based on the first-order, global higher-order (HSDT), global–local higher-order (GLHT), and Reddy’s higher-order (RHSDT) shear deformation theories using Navier’s solution. Due to the zig-zag nature of the displacement field in the layerwise theory, which enables the method to accurately predict the transverse shear deformation, it is expected that the results of the present approach demonstrate better accuracy compared with those of HSDT. The effect of the temperature field on the natural frequencies of hinged–hinged and clamped–clamped FGS beams are examined in Table 5. The results of the present method are compared successfully with the FSDT solutions of reference16 and the results of ABAQUS. The FG face sheet is assumed to be a mixture of aluminum (Al) and zirconia (ZrO2) and the core layer is made of aluminum. The beam is stacked as ZrO2–Al/Al/Al–ZrO2. The thermoelastic material properties of aluminum and zirconia are as follows16 Al: Em=70 GPa, vm,=0.3, ρm=2707 kg/m3,αm=2.3×10-5 l/K, Km=204 W/mK
ZrO2:Ec=151 GPa,vc=0.3,ρc=3000 kg/m3,αc=1.0×0-5 1/K,Km=2.09 W/mK

sec.title: Parametric study
sec.p:
Figure 2 compares the effects of non-uniform and uniform temperature change on the first two non-dimensional natural frequencies of clamped FGS sandwich beams. This problem is also solved based on FSDT using DQM and the results are compared with those obtained by layerwise theory. The maximum difference between the FSDT predictions and those of LW-DQ is about 5% for the first non-dimensional natural frequency but the FSDT solution diverges more from the accurate results for higher-order frequencies. It is found that the non-dimensional frequency decreases with increasing temperature change. Also, for an identical temperature change, the uniform temperature variation has more effect on the frequency than the non-uniform temperature one. Figure 2.
(a) and (b) Effects of the uniform and non-uniform temperature change on the first two dimensionless frequencies of clamped FGS beams. FGS, functionally graded sandwich.

Figures 3 and 4 illustrate the effects of 
hf/h
 ratios and volume fraction indices versus variation of the temperature change on the natural frequencies, respectively. Again a comparative solution with FSDT results is provided which can be served as benchmarks for future analyses. It is observed that the non-dimensional frequency parameter increases with either the increase of thickness ratio or the decrease of volume fraction index. That is due to the increase of ceramic volume fraction which in turn leads to the forming of a stiffer beam. Figure 5 exhibits the effects of temperature change on the first, second, third, and fifth mode shapes of clamped–clamped FGS beams. The different temperature fields are denoted as case 1 (
ΔTU=ΔTL=300
) and case 2 (
ΔTU=300, ΔTL=0
). The fourth mode is an axial deformation mode and is not shown. As one can expect, the mode shapes are similar for both cases. This is because the mode shapes of FGS beams mainly depend on their mechanical boundary conditions.
Figure 3.
Effects of face to beam thickness ratios on dimensionless frequencies of clamped FGS beams with respect to non-uniform temperature change (- - - - : FSDT, ____ : LW-DQ). FGS, functionally graded sandwich; FSDT, first-order shear deformation theory.

Figure 4.
(a) and (b). Effects of volume fraction indices on dimensionless frequencies of clamped FGS beams with respect to non-uniform temperature change (- - - - : FSDT, _______ : LW-DQ). FGS, functionally graded sandwich; FSDT, first-order shear deformation theory.

Figure 5.
Comparison of mode shapes of FGS beams under different temperature fields: case 1 (
ΔTU=ΔTL=300
) and case 2 (
ΔTU=300, ΔTL=0
); (a) the first mode shape, (b) the second mode shape, (c) the third mode shape, and (d) the fifth mode shape (
ξ=xL
). FGS, functionally graded sandwich.

Table 6 lists the effects of foundation parameters, volume fraction index, and non-uniform temperature changes on the non-dimensional natural frequencies of hinged FGS beams based on FSDT and layerwise theory. As it is expected, the frequency increases with the increasing of foundation moduli. Furthermore, it is demonstrated that the discrepancy between the presented solutions decreases by increasing the three aforementioned parameters. Table 6.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A 2D elasticity-based layerwise theory is employed to study the free vibration behavior of FGS beams under thermal environment resting on Winkler–Pasternak elastic foundations. To present a realistic and practical method, the thermally induced stresses are first determined by solving the thermoelastic equilibrium equations. Afterwards, the frequencies of the beam are calculated by considering predetermined thermally induced stresses. The through-the-thickness discretized governing differential equations are obtained by means of Hamilton’s principle together with layerwise theory. Then, the resulting equations of motion are solved using DQM. The present model is validated by comparing the solution with the FE results obtained by ABAQUS software and the available predictions in the literature. Effects of several impressive parameters such as volume fraction index, aspect ratio, temperature rise, foundation stiffness, thickness of FGM layers, and boundary conditions on the free vibration characteristic of FGS beams are comprehensively investigated. The obtained results demonstrate that the layerwise-DQ method is capable of generating accurate results with less effort compared to ESLTs or FE solution. Concerning the thermal effects, it is found that the temperature has a significant effect on the free vibration characteristic of FGS beams.

sec.title: Funding
sec.p: This research received no specific grant from any funding agency in the public, commercial, or not-for-profit sectors.
